title: Edmund Gunter
summary: Edmund Gunter (1581 – 10 December 1626), was an English clergyman, mathematician, geometer and astronomer[1] of Welsh descent.  He is best remembered for his mathematical contributions which include the invention of the Gunter's chain, the Gunter's quadrant, and the Gunter's scale. In 1620, he invented the first successful analogue device[2] which he developed to calculate logarithmic tangents.[3]
